metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: XML WSDL
WSDL Documents
An WSDL document describes a web service. It specifies the location of the service, and the methods of the service, using these major elements:
content.html: An WSDL document describes a web service. It specifies the location of the service, and the methods of the service, using these major elements:

content.code_html:
Element Description
<types> Defines the (XML Schema) data types used by the web service
<message> Defines the data elements for each operation
<portType> Describes the operations that can be performed and the messages involved.
<binding> Defines the protocol and data format for each port type

content.text: The main structure of a WSDL document looks like this:
content.html: The main structure of a WSDL document looks like this:

content.code:
<definitions>


<types>


data type definitions........

</types>


<message>


definition of the data being communicated....

</message>


<portType>


set of operations......

</portType>


<binding>


protocol and data format specification....

</binding>


</definitions>
content.code_html:
<definitions>

<types>
  data type definitions........
</types>

<message>
  definition of the data being communicated....
</message>

<portType>
  set of operations......
</portType>

<binding>
  protocol and data format specification....
</binding>

</definitions>

content.text: WSDL Example
This is a simplified fraction of a WSDL document:
content.html: This is a simplified fraction of a WSDL document:

content.code:
<message name="getTermRequest">


<part name="term" type="xs:string"/>

</message>


<message name="getTermResponse">


<part name="value" type="xs:string"/>

</message>


<portType name="glossaryTerms">


<operation name="getTerm">


<input message="getTermRequest"/>


<output message="getTermResponse"/>


</operation>

</portType>
content.code_html:
<message name="getTermRequest">
  <part name="term" type="xs:string"/>
</message>

<message name="getTermResponse">
  <part name="value" type="xs:string"/>
</message>

<portType name="glossaryTerms">
  <operation name="getTerm">
    <input message="getTermRequest"/>
    <output message="getTermResponse"/>
  </operation>
</portType>

content.text: In this example the <portType> element defines "glossaryTerms" as the name of a port , and "getTerm" as the name of an operation .
content.html: In this example the <portType> element defines "glossaryTerms" as the name of a port, and "getTerm" as the name of an operation.

content.text: The "getTerm" operation has an input message called "getTermRequest" and an output message called "getTermResponse".
content.html: The "getTerm" operation has an input message called "getTermRequest" and an output message called "getTermResponse".

content.text: The <message> elements define the parts of each message and the associated data types.
content.html: The <message> elements define the parts of each message and the associated data types.

content.text: The <portType> Element
The <portType> element defines a web service , the operations that can be performed, and the messages that are involved.
content.html: The <portType> element defines a web service, the operations that can be performed, and the messages that are involved.

content.text: The request-response type is the most common operation type, but WSDL defines four types:
content.html: The request-response type is the most common operation type, but WSDL defines four types:

content.code_html:
Type Definition
One-way The operation can receive a message but will not return a response
Request-response The operation can receive a request and will return a response
Solicit-response The operation can send a request and will wait for a response
Notification The operation can send a message but will not wait for a response

content.text: WSDL One-Way Operation
A one-way operation example:
content.html: A one-way operation example:

content.code:
<message name="newTermValues">


<part name="term" type="xs:string"/>


<part name="value" type="xs:string"/>

</message>


<portType name="glossaryTerms">


<operation name="setTerm">


<input name="newTerm" message="newTermValues"/>


</operation>

</portType >
content.code_html:
<message name="newTermValues">
  <part name="term" type="xs:string"/>
  <part name="value" type="xs:string"/>
</message>

<portType name="glossaryTerms">
  <operation name="setTerm">
    <input name="newTerm" message="newTermValues"/>
  </operation>
</portType >

content.text: In the example above, the portType "glossaryTerms" defines a one-way operation called "setTerm".
content.html: In the example above, the portType "glossaryTerms" defines a one-way operation called "setTerm".

content.text: The "setTerm" operation allows input of new glossary terms messages using a "newTermValues" message with the input parameters "term" and "value". However, no output is defined for the operation.
content.html: The "setTerm" operation allows input of new glossary terms messages using a "newTermValues" message with the input parameters "term" and "value". However, no output is defined for the operation.

content.text: WSDL Request-Response Operation
A request-response operation example:
content.html: A request-response operation example:

content.code:
<message name="getTermRequest">


<part name="term" type="xs:string"/>

</message>


<message name="getTermResponse">


<part name="value" type="xs:string"/>

</message>


<portType name="glossaryTerms">


<operation name="getTerm">


<input message="getTermRequest"/>


<output message="getTermResponse"/>


</operation>

</portType>
content.code_html:
<message name="getTermRequest">
  <part name="term" type="xs:string"/>
</message>

<message name="getTermResponse">
  <part name="value" type="xs:string"/>
</message>

<portType name="glossaryTerms">
  <operation name="getTerm">
    <input message="getTermRequest"/>
    <output message="getTermResponse"/>
  </operation>
</portType>

content.text: In the example above, the portType "glossaryTerms" defines a request-response operation called "getTerm".
content.html: In the example above, the portType "glossaryTerms" defines a request-response operation called "getTerm".

content.text: The "getTerm" operation requires an input message called "getTermRequest" with a parameter called "term", and will return an output message called "getTermResponse" with a parameter called "value".
content.html: The "getTerm" operation requires an input message called "getTermRequest" with a parameter called "term", and will return an output message called "getTermResponse" with a parameter called "value".

content.text: WSDL Binding to SOAP
WSDL bindings defines the message format and protocol details for a web service.
content.html: WSDL bindings defines the message format and protocol details for a web service.

content.text: A request-response operation example:
content.html: A request-response operation example:

content.code:
<message name="getTermRequest">


<part name="term" type="xs:string"/>

</message>


<message name="getTermResponse">


<part name="value" type="xs:string"/>

</message>


<portType name="glossaryTerms">


<operation name="getTerm">


<input message="getTermRequest"/>


<output message="getTermResponse"/>


</operation>

</portType>


<binding type="glossaryTerms" name="b1">

<soap:binding style="document"
transport="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/http" />

<operation>

<soap:operation
soapAction="http://example.com/getTerm"/>

<input><soap:body use="literal"/></input>

<output><soap:body use="literal"/></output>


</operation>

</binding>
content.code_html:
<message name="getTermRequest">
  <part name="term" type="xs:string"/>
</message>

<message name="getTermResponse">
  <part name="value" type="xs:string"/>
</message>

<portType name="glossaryTerms">
  <operation name="getTerm">
    <input message="getTermRequest"/>
    <output message="getTermResponse"/>
  </operation>
</portType>

<binding type="glossaryTerms" name="b1">
   <soap:binding style="document"
   transport="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/http" />
   <operation>
     <soap:operation soapAction="http://example.com/getTerm"/>
     <input><soap:body use="literal"/></input>
     <output><soap:body use="literal"/></output>
  </operation>
</binding>

content.text: The binding element has two attributes - name and type.
content.html: The binding element has two attributes - name and type.

content.text: The name attribute (you can use any name you want) defines the name of the binding, and the type attribute points to the port for the binding, in this case the "glossaryTerms" port.
content.html: The name attribute (you can use any name you want) defines the name of the binding, and the type attribute points to the port for the binding, in this case the "glossaryTerms" port.

content.text: The soap:binding element has two attributes - style and transport.
content.html: The soap:binding element has two attributes - style and transport.

content.text: The style attribute can be "rpc" or "document". In this case we use document. The transport attribute defines the SOAP protocol to use. In this case we use HTTP.
content.html: The style attribute can be "rpc" or "document". In this case we use document. The transport attribute defines the SOAP protocol to use. In this case we use HTTP.

content.text: The operation element defines each operation that the portType exposes.
content.html: The operation element defines each operation that the portType exposes.

content.text: For each operation the corresponding SOAP action has to be defined. You must also specify how the input and output are encoded. In this case we use "literal".
content.html: For each operation the corresponding SOAP action has to be defined. You must also specify how the input and output are encoded. In this case we use "literal".
